(only allowed between 11:00 p.m.–5:00 a.m.) It is mandatory for all Venezuelan television station to broadcast a short presentation, before the broadcast of any programs, made by the same channel, where the type of program (recreational, informational, mixed, etc.), type of production (domestic or national independent) elements include containing (such as language, health, sex and/or violence) and lastly the rating of the program. == See also == * [[Motion picture content rating system]] * [[Video game content rating system]] * [[Watershed (broadcasting)]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Entertainment rating organizations|*]] [[Category:Media content ratings systems|*]] [[Category:Self-censorship]]

revision.comment: /* Fallout and separate careers */
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Imre Kiralfy | image = Imre-Kiralfy.jpg | caption = Imre Kiralfy in 1891 | birth_name = Imre Königsbaum | birth_date = {{birth date|1845|1|}} | birth_place = [[Pest, Hungary|Austro-Hungarian empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1919|4|28|1845|1|1}} | death_place = [[Brighton]], [[England]] | occupation = Dancer, producer | children = [[Edgar Kiralfy]] | spouse = Marie Graham (1851–1942) | years_active = 1849–1908 }} {{Infobox person | name = Bolossy Kiralfy | image = Bolossy Kiralfy.jpeg | caption = Caricature of Bolossy Kiralfy | birth_name = Bolossy Königsbaum | birth_date = {{birth date|1848|1|}} | birth_place = [[Pest, Hungary|Austro-Hungarian empire]] | death_date = {{death year and age|1932|1848|}} | death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | occupation = Dancer, director, producer }} '''Imre Kirafly and [[Bolossy Kiralfy]]''' were highly influential [[burlesque]] and [[spectacle]] producers in [[Europe]] and the [[United States]] toward the end of the 19th century. The brothers paved the way for many of our modern day spectacles.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} With backgrounds in music and dance, these performers turned producers dazzled [[New York City]] with theatrical wonders. The brothers had a long and successful partnership and even continued to have success in their individual careers. From [[folk dancing]] in Europe to directing and producing in the United States, the Kiralfys spent their lives astounding audiences with unseen visual phenomenon and were never afraid to push the boundaries earning them a special place in entertainment history. == Family life == [[File:Imre Kiralfy's Venice the bride of the sea, performance poster, 1891.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Imre Kiralfy's greatest of all spectacles, ''[[Venice in London|Venice, The Bride of the Sea]]'' at the [[Olympia, London]], featured lluminated aquatic festivities.]] The Kiralfy Brothers, Imre (1845-1919) and Bolossy (1848-1932), were the eldest of seven siblings born in the 1840s in [[Budapest]] during the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848|Hungarian Revolution]], in which their father, Jacob Königsbaum, was ruined. When they were young children, Imre and Bolossy began to teach themselves to dance. They continued for years until their father caught them and promptly enrolled them in dance classes.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Creator of Great Musical Spectacles: An Autobiography|date=1988|publisher=Mich: UMI Research Press|page=10}} Soon, they were dancing at large venues such as the Hungarian Circus. There the brothers first performed under the name “Kiralfy” instead of their family name of Königsbaum; the boys’ father changed their name to prevent them from being recognized as the sons of a revolutionary.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy,Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=11}} They were never recognized, though over the years, there were a number of close encounters with [[Austria-Hungary|Austria]]n police, during many of which their father was nearly arrested. Jacob Königsbaum and their mother, Anna (Rosa) Weisberger, were highly supportive of their sons’ career. They gave up their clothing business to take the brothers on tour through [[Europe]].{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=12}} For many years, the family continued to travel, touring all through both [[Eastern Europe|Eastern]] and [[Western Europe]], while the three of the four younger siblings went to school and learned dance. The Kiralfy family motto was “All the World’s a Stage.”{{cite book|last1=Tenneriello|first1=Susan|title=Spectacle Culture and American Identity: 1815-1940|date=2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York, NY|page=101}} Eventually, their sisters Haniola, Emile and Katie, as well as their youngest brother Arnold joined Imre and Bolossy in the dance industry. Only their brother Ronald was uninterested in dance.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=55}} == Early career and education == As teenagers in the 1860s, Bolossy and Imre travelled to [[Paris]], where they were immediately taken with theatrical spectacle.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=55}} Bolossy believes he first developed his theory of theatre in the city:
Real musical theatre had to be popular theatre, attracting an audience from all segments of society. It had to embody in logical form all aspects of the theatre – music, lyrics, dance and drama – in a production that was usually greater than the sum of its parts. It had to have a meaningful story with a universal theme, and it had to have a hero or heroine with whom the audience could sympathize.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=61}}
[[File:Victorien Sardou - Dolores.jpg|thumb|Bolossy Kiralfy's grand Parisian production, ''Dolores'' by Victorien Sardou]] Imre and Bolossy both trained at the [[Paris Opera Ballet|Opera Ballet]] but they refused to become permanent performers.{{cite journal|last1=Craig|first1=Jenifer|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator of Great Musical Spectacles: An Autobiography by Barbara M. Barker; Bolossy Kiralfy|journal=Dance Research Journal|date=1990|volume=22|issue=2|page=35}} Bolossy reflects on his training in [[Paris]]:
There is no question that in Paris I acquired my training, not only in the finest Ballet technique from Monsieur Barres, but in the areas of production and management. The presentations at the Theatre Francais taught me dramatic staging. My experience at the Theatre de la Porte-Saint-Martin and at the Chatelet gave me the ability to produce big spectacular numbers. At the Opera I learned the choreography that would help me to plan my lavish musical productions. And it was there that my encounters with the artists proved how exciting and challenging the work of producers and directors could be.Bolossy Kiralfy
Bolossy Kiralfy was 26 when he retired as a performer and began the second phase of his career where he focused on producing and choreographing. He adapted European productions to the United States. The Kiralfy Brothers had a 13-year-long producing partnership. According to Bolossy Kiralfy, “The American public not only became educated of our large dance extravaganzas, they demanded them in all musical productions.” {{cite journal|last1=Craig|first1=Jenifer|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator of Great Musical Spectacles: An Autobiography by Barbara M. Barker; Bolossy Kiralfy|journal=Dance Research Journal|date=1990|volume=22|issue=2|page=36}} When they travelled to [[New York City]] in May 1869, the Kiralfy Brothers may already have envisioned how to produce their ideas of spectacle on stage.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=81}} For four years, the family continued to tour as dancers, until eventually being contracted by [[Niblo's Garden]], just after the theatre’s immense success with ''[[The Black Crook]]''.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=84}} Their first foray into the production side of theatre came in 1871, with the [[pantomime]] ''[[Humpty Dumpty]]'' at the Olympic, in which the “Kiralfy Troupe,” as they had come to be known, were performing. The reviewers of the production praised both the dancing and the scenery greatly, declaring the latter to be “of exceptional beauty”.{{cite news|title=Amusements-Theatrical-Pantomime at the Olympic|issue=September 1st|publisher=New York Times|date=1871|location=New York, NY}} This “exceptional beauty” would become a common theme in reviews of the Kiralfy Brothers' productions. '''''The Black Crook''''' [[File:The Black Crook.jpg|thumb|''The Black Crook'']] In August 1873, the brothers first produced their own musical spectacle, a revival of ''[[The Black Crook]]'' at [[Niblo's Garden]]. They added musical numbers, improved the costumes (beyond exposing the legs of the actresses), and strengthened the dance numbers. According to Bolossy Kiralfy, their revival was an immense success, playing over one hundred performances before going on tour and breaking [[Niblo's Garden]]'s record number of performances of a revival.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=94}} Their production, featuring actors such as [[George Atkins (actor)|George Atkins]], E.K. Collier, and W. Martin, as well as the Kiralfy sisters’ dancing talents, was later revived from November 1874 to January 1875.{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|pages=406, 555|edition=Vol. IX. 1870-1875}} With this production, the brothers achieved their goal of making popular theatre, and they made a strong effort to elevate ''The Black Crook'' into a slightly higher class of theatre. '''''The Deluge, or Paradise Lost''''' The next year, they imported the French spectacle ''The Deluge'' to [[Niblo's Garden]], and were noted for producing rain on stage.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=94}} ''The Deluge'', otherwise known as ''Paradise Lost,'' opened [[Niblo's Garden]]'s 1874-1875 season, on September 4, 1874. This production was called a “delectability” by the historian George Odell. Its players included actresses Julia Seamen, Lillie McDonald and Katie New, as well as the Kiralfy Sisters as dancers. ''The Deluge'' ran until November 14, 1874 and a competing theater company, [[Bryant's Minstrels]], opened their own ''The Deluge'' on the same day.{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|page=548|edition=Vol. IX. 1870-1875}} Odell said it brought “a veritable flood-tide of success”.{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|page=608|edition=Vol. IX. 1870-1875}} When one of the many revivals of the Kiralfy Brothers’ production was brought to the [[Walnut Street Theatre]] in [[Philadelphia]] in April 1879, reviewers praised the ballet and scenery, while essentially ignoring the acting. One reviewer comments that the sets of “Pandemonium, [[the Garden of Eden]], and the Temple of Enoch were wonderful to behold, and were master-pieces of scenic painting,” and goes on to note that, because the piece was under the direction of the Kiralfys, it would “undoubtedly draw full houses”.{{cite news|last1=Tryniski|first1=Thomas M.|title=Drama in the United States|publisher=The New York Mirror|date=1880}} ''The Deluge'' is a perfect example of the Kiralfys’ mastery of the key concepts of [[burlesque]]; the plot was weak but the gorgeous set, astonishing special effects, and beautiful girls served well to cover this up. '''''Around the World in Eighty Days''''' [[File:Around the World in 80 days.jpg|thumb|The Kiralfy Brothers' amazing adaptation of [[Jules Verne]]'s ''[[Around the World in 80 Days]]'' (1877)]] On August 28, 1875, the Kiralfy Brothers put up, “in spectacular style,” ''[[Around the World in Eighty Days]]'' at the New York [[Academy of Music (New York City)|Academy of Music]].{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|page=66|edition=Vol. X. 1875-1879}} According to Bolossy Kiralfy, their goal with the production was to “convert American theatre audiences into enthusiasts for the French style of musical spectacle” which so inspired the brothers.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=93}} ''Around the World in Eighty Days'' based on the [[Jules Verne]] novel and adapted for the stage by Michael d’Ennery, was another Parisian import.{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|page=120|edition=Vol. X. 1875-1879}} To mount the show in the [[United States]], the brothers re-created the scenery and costumes from the [[Paris]] production as precisely as possible, and hired all the cast and crew members, except for the principal speaking roles, from the [[Théâtre de la Porte Saint-Martin]], where the original production was performed.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=97}} In terms of special effects, the brothers rented an elephant for $150 per week, brought a steam engine from Europe to run automation, and created a new stage deck for the Academy of Music to accommodate for a sinking steam ship.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=98}} Audiences loved the depictions of foreign attractions such as the [[Suez Canal]], [[Calcutta]], and the [[Taj Mahal]]. The Kiralfys were immediately praised for their use of pastel backgrounds which please the eye but do not distract from performance. They were also some of the first American producers to utilize realistic set design. For example, their trees looked like actual trees and not theatrical renditions of trees.{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Cecil A.|last2=Litton|first2=Glenn|title=Musical Comedy in America: From The Black Crook to South Pacific, From The King & I to Sweeney Todd|date=1987|publisher=Routledge|page=29|accessdate=14 December 2014}} They convinced Jules Verne to add a bit about a hot air balloon to the already-extensive adventures of [[Phileas Fogg]] and his companions so that the Kiralfys could put a real [[helium]] balloon onstage to be operated by wires.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=98}} Aside from adding special effects, few changes were made to the Paris production. They added the ''Around the World Waltz'' and a curtain for scene changes that was in the shape of a fan. The Kiralfy production was larger than the Paris production, having a cast of 35 principal actors, a ballet corps, and over 200 ensemble members.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=230}} ''Around the World in Eighty Days'' opened at the Academy of Music, after a legal challenge due to another New York troupe trying to mount the same Paris production, and it was a major hit. The special effects and exciting story attracted large audiences consistently. It became so popular that the [[President of the United States]] attended a performance. President [[Ulysses S. Grant]], who attended a performance on September 17, 1875 with Secretary [[George M. Robeson]], General [[Orville E. Babcock]], and former-Attorney General [[George Henry Williams]], “seemed to be much pleased with the brilliant spectacle”.{{cite news|title=President Grant|publisher=New York Times|date=September 18, 1875}} After the production closed in October at the Academy of Music, it went on tour to the outer boroughs for two weeks, until it reached the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music]], during Christmas week in 1875.{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|page=729|edition=Vol. X. 1875-1879}} Yet, like ''The Deluge'', this Kiralfy Brothers production did not end here. The first of a long line of expansive revivals of ''Around the World in Eighty Days'' opened again at Niblo's Garden on January 22, 1877. It was presented at Niblo's Garden nine times, together with a series of very successful tours and revivals between 1881 and 1892 throughout New York City and the United States. Some of the houses for ''Around the World'' included [[J.H. Haverly|Haverly’s Theatre]] in Brooklyn, the [[Sara Adler|Novelty Theatre]] in Brooklyn, and the [[Pike's Opera House|Grand Opera House]], the [[48th Street Theatre|Windsor Theatre]], and the [[Bushwick, Brooklyn|Amphion Academy]].{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=George C.D.|title=Annals of the New York Stage|date=1970|publisher=Ams Pr Inc|edition=Vol. XI.-XIV. 1882-1891}} For the audience and the producers, much of the appeal in such frequent productions lay in the fluidity of the plot, which allowed many opportunities for additions to the story, scenery and dance.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=231}} The fantastic situations [[Phileas Fogg]] and company get into on their trip around the world, allow for inserts and interpretation. Due to their success with this work, the brothers bought a property at 39 [[Washington Square Park|Washington Square]], which they used for offices and residence until 1921.{{cite book|last1=Kiralfy|first1=Bolossy|editor1-last=Barker|editor1-first=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator Of Great Musical Spectacles|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|location=Ann Arbor, Mich.|page=99}} '''''Excelsior''''' [[File:Kiralfy's Excelsior.jpg|thumb|''Excelsior'' (1883), a Kiralfy Brothers spectacle]] When the electric lightbulb was commercialized around 1880, the Kiralfy brothers took full advantage. They quickly put a production of ''Excelsior'' into the works with plans to be lit electrically for special effects scenes. The spectacle was presented at Niblo's Garden in 1883. There was still use of gas-lighting and they were not the first ones to employ electric lighting (they, themselves, had previously used electric light in their revival of ''The Black Crook'') but they were the first and only production to be lit under the personal direction of [[Thomas Edison]]. In their production, the invention of incandescent light was celebrated along with the invention of the [[telegraph]] as incorporated in a dance of telegraph messengers. Not a word was spoken in the production and ''Excelsior'' is widely regarded as the Kiralfys’ most important work. That goes to show the Kiralfys’ expertise in dance and spectacle.{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Cecil A.|last2=Litton|first2=Glenn|title=Musical Comedy in America: From The Black Crook to South Pacific, From The King & I to Sweeney Todd|date=1987|publisher=Routledge|page=29|accessdate=14 December 2014}} == Fallout and separate careers == The Kiralfy Brothers had a 13-year long producing partnership. In 1887, Imre and Bolossy Kiralfy had a falling out and the firm disbanded, driving Bolossy and Imre to produce outdoor spectacles. Neither publicly addressed the split, although, Bolossy intimated that his brother was making business deals behind his back. Upon their split, Bolossy continued to work in fantasy and fable whereas Imre pressed on with progressive era productions filled with science, technology, and machinery.{{cite book|last1=Tenneriello|first1=Susan|title=Spectacle Culture and American Identity: 1815-1940|date=2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York, NY|page=97}}[[File:The Barnum and Bailey Greatest Show on Earth…Imre Kiralfy's Columbus.jpg|thumb|The Barnum and Bailey Greatest Show on Earth: Imre Kiralfy's ''Columbus and the Discovery of America'' (1892)]] '''Imre Kiralfy after the split''' [[File:Empress Hall, Fulham 1937.jpg|thumb|left|Aerial view of Empress Hall]] Imre Kiralfy’s ''The Fall of Rome'' was produced on [[Staten Island]] with 2,000 performers, a grand number at the time. In 1892, to mark the 400th anniversary of Columbus' "founding" of America, he produced ''Columbus and the Discovery of America'' at the [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden Theatre]]. It was later featured at the [[Auditorium Theatre]] at the Chicago [[World’s Columbian Exposition]]. Imre Kiralfy also premiered his show ''America'' at the Chicago World’s Fair which was picked up by the [[Metropolitan Opera House (39th Street)|Metropolitan Opera House]] in 1893. ''[[Life magazine]]'' in quoted as response to the production “Kiralfy out-Kiralfy’s himself”{{cite book|last1=Tennerielo|first1=Susan|title=Spectacle Culture and American Identity: 1815-1940|date=2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York, NY|page=102}} Imre Kiralfy then moved to England where he created even larger spectacles.{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Cecil A.|last2=Litton|first2=Glenn|title=Musical Comedy in America: From The Black Crook to South Pacific, From The King & I to Sweeney Todd|date=1987|publisher=Routledge|page=30}} The twenty-four acre [[Earl's Court Exhibition Centre]] grounds were rebuilt in 1894 by Imre Kiralfy in a Mughal Indian style. ''The Empire of India Exhibition'' opened the site in 1895, and was the first of a series of annual exhibitions there, which drew heavily on the abundance of transport links in the area to attract a mass audience. Highlights of the site included the two-storey Empress Hall, built for Kiralfy in [[Fulham]] which could seat 6,000 viewers for his spectaculars, and the 300-feet high [[Great Wheel]] whose forty carriages could each accommodate thirty people.{{cite web |title=Empress Theatre/Hall|author=Arthur Lloyd|url=http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/EmpressHall.htm|date=|accessdate=24 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Empire of India Exhibition, 1895|url=http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/makingbritain/content/empire-india-exhibition-1895|website=The Open University|publisher=The Open University|accessdate=13 December 2014}} Imre Kiralfy became a British citizen in 1901.{{cite web|last1=Pes|first1=Javier|title=Kiralfy, Imre (1845-1919)|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/53347|website=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=January 27, 2014}} The renowned producer died on April 28, 1919 at age 74 in [[Brighton]], [[England]].{{cite news|title=Imre Kiralfy Dead in England|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/04/29/96297996.pdf|accessdate=13 December 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=April 29, 1919}} '''Bolossy Kiralfy after the split''' [[File:Mathias Sandorf.jpg|thumb|upright|Bolossy Kiralfy's spectacular production of [[Jules Verne]]'s ''[[Mathias Sandorf]]'' (1888)]] During his time alone, Blossy Kiralfy focused a lot on outdoor theatre. In [[London]] he created ''Venice in London'', which included a lake and water canals. A few years later, in [[Portland, Oregon]], he produced ''Carnival in Venice''. According to Bolossy, this production in Portland required “a huge open air theatre with a particularly broad canal connected to a lake. The four hundred foot stage was the largest ever constructed in the Northwest and allowed me to put two hundred performers in action in one scene. I could still hide myself and cruise the show in a gondola to evaluate the performance.” {{cite book|last1=Barker|first1=Barbara M.|title=Bolossy Kiralfy, Creator of Great Musical Spectacles: An Autobiography|date=1988|publisher=UMI Research Press|page=196}} In 1888, Bolossy returned from his trip to Europe and brought two new spectacles to America, ''[[Mathias Sandorf]]'' and ''Antiope''. ''Mathias Sandorf'' is a play by [[Jules Verne]]. Bolossy purchased the play itself along with the scenery, costumes and effects used in the original production. Kiralfy had several interviews with Jules Verne and [[William Busnach]] to improve certain scenes and adapt them for American audiences. Kiralfy also introduced two new ballets in this production; one of them is called ''America'' and required 120 performers; the other one is called ''The Fete of Storks'' and required no less than 200 performers. In this production, Kiralfy included performers like the James troupe of eccentric games, and Alexandrov Brothers, the famous Russian musical clowns.{{cite news|title=With Two New Spectacles, Return From Europe of Bolossy Kiralfy with Some Treasures|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1888/06/25/112635218.pdf|publisher=The New York Times|date=June 25, 1888}} The other production that Kiralfy brought was the new ballet ''Antiope'' which opened at London first. Kiralfy promised this ballet to be more brilliant and effective than the ''Excelsior'', which was claimed to be best ballet of the time. The production featured 350 magnificent costumes designed by [[William Charles John Pitcher|Wilhelm]]}. Kiralfy introduced some novel features in this production, one of which was an eccentric boat moving about on real water.{{cite news|title=With Two New Spectacles, Return From Europe of Bolossy Kiralfy with Some Treasures|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1888/06/25/112635218.pdf|publisher=The New York Times|date=June 25, 1888}} Bolossy Kiralfy died in 1932 at the age of 84 in New York City. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kiralfy Brothers}} [[Category:Burlesque performers]] [[Category:Sibling duos]] [[Category:Theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Hungarian Jews]] [[Category:History of the London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham]] [[Category:Burials at Kensal Green Cemetery]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The Two Foscari'' (Byron)}} [[File:Francesco Hayez - The Two Foscari - WGA11217.jpg|thumb|Francesco Foscari banishing his son Jacopo on the charge of treasonable correspondence while in exile. Painting by [[Francesco Hayez]], circa 1852.]] '''''The Two Foscari: An Historical Tragedy''''' (1821) is a verse play in five acts by [[Lord Byron]]. The plot, set in [[Venice]] in the mid 15th century, is loosely based on the true story of the downfall of [[Doge of Venice|doge]] [[Francesco Foscari]] and his son Jacopo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.credoreference.com/entry/orioncurious/two_foscari_the |title=Two Foscari, The |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2002 |work=Brewer's Curious Titles |publisher=Cassell |accessdate=19 June 2013}}</ref> Byron's play formed the basis of [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s opera ''[[I due Foscari]]''.
== Synopsis ==
Jacopo Foscari, son of the Doge of Venice, has twice been exiled, once for corruption and once for complicity in the murder of Donato, a member of the [[Council of Ten]]. He has been recalled from his second exile to answer the capital charge of treason, and as the play opens he is between sessions of interrogation on the rack. The Council decide to sentence him to a third exile, this time perpetual, rather than to death. His father Doge Francesco Foscari signs the sentence of exile, though his spirit is broken by this new disgrace. Jacopo's patriotic spirit cannot brook such a sentence, he longs to die, and he duly does die of a broken heart. The Council of Ten orders the Doge to abdicate, and, as the bells begin to toll to signify the election of a new Doge, the old one falls and dies.
== Composition and publication == [[File:The Two Foscari, Sardanapalus, and Cain.jpg|thumb|150px|First edition title page]] Byron wrote ''The Two Foscari'' in [[Ravenna]] in less than a month, between 12 June and 9 July 1821.<ref>{{Royal Collection|1047665|The Two Foscari: an historical tragedy in five acts}}</ref> It was published by [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]] on 19 December 1821 in the same volume as his ''[[Sardanapalus (play)|Sardanapalus]]'' and ''[[Cain (play)|Cain]]''. Byron originally intended to dedicate ''The Two Foscari'' to his friend Sir [[Walter Scott]], but in the event he transferred that dedication to ''Cain'' and left ''Foscari'' without one.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Leslie A. |editor1-last=Marchand |title=Born for Opposition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T8ArAAAAYAAJ&q=%22the+first+two+appeared+without%22&dq=%22the+first+two+appeared+without%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vg3GUcrtLMfOOMqEgIgI&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg |accessdate=22 June 2013 |series=Byron’s Letters and Journals, Volume 8 |year=1978 |publisher=John Murray |location=London |isbn=0719534518 }}</ref> He added an appendix to ''The Two Foscari'' in which he launched a stinging attack on what he considered the hypocrisies of the [[Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom|Poet Laureate]], [[Robert Southey]]. Southey responded in a letter to a London newspaper in which he dared Byron to attack him again. Byron initially wanted to challenge Southey to a duel, but then turned instead to poetry and wrote his stinging satire ''[[The Vision of Judgment]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Wolfson |first1=Susan J. |authorlink1=Susan J. Wolfson |editor1-first=Drummond |editor1-last=Bone |editor1-link=Drummond Bone |title=The Cambridge Companion to Byron |year=2004 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |isbn=0521781469 |page=173 |chapter=''The Vision of Judgment'' and the Visions of "Author" }}</ref>
== ''The Two Foscari'' in other media ==
Verdi's opera ''I due Foscari'', with a [[libretto]] by [[Francesco Maria Piave]], was based on Byron's play.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Michael |editor1-last=Kennedy |editor1-link=Michael Kennedy (music critic) |title=The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music |year=1980 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=London |isbn=0193113201 |page=191 }}</ref> It also inspired two paintings, ''Les deux Foscari'' by [[Eugène Delacroix|Delacroix]], and ''L'ultimo abboccamento di Jacopo Foscari con la propria famiglia prima di partire per l'esilio cui era stato condannato'' by [[Francesco Hayez]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ekelhart |first1=Christine |title=Französische Zeichnungen und Aquarelle des 19. und 20. Jahrhundert der Albertina |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rQalYIj6yHAC&pg=PA210&dq=chantilly+delacroix+%22les+deux+foscari%22+byron&hl=en |accessdate=23 June 2013 |year=2007 |publisher=Böhlau |location=Wien |isbn=9783205775997 |page=210 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=De Vecchi |first1=Pierluigi |last2=Vergani |first2=Graziano Alfredo |title=La rappresentazione della città nella pittura italiana |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uUJIAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Il+dipinto+di+Hayez+qui+presentato+si+ispira+a+un+poema+di+Byron%22&dq=%22Il+dipinto+di+Hayez+qui+presentato+si+ispira+a+un+poema+di+Byron%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YxHCUemvFq2b0wWn24DYCA&ved=0CCQQ6AewAA |accessdate=23 June 2013 |year=c. 2003 |publisher=Silvana |location=Milano |isbn=8882156753 |page=294 }}</ref>
== Footnotes ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://petercochran.files.wordpress.com/2009/03/the_two_foscari.pdf An edition of ''The Two Foscari'' by Peter Cochran]
{{Byron}}

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox video game |title = Tzar: The Burden of the Crown |image = Tzarburdenofthecrownbox.jpg |developer = [[Haemimont Games]] |publisher = [[Take-Two Interactive]]
[[FX Interactive]] (Italy and Spain) |designer = Vesselin Handjiev |engine = |released = March 31, 2000 |genre = [[Real-time strategy]] |modes = [[Single player]] [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }}'''''Tzar: The Burden of the Crown''''' is a [[real-time strategy]] game for the [[Personal computer|PC]] published by [[Take-Two Interactive]] and developed by the [[Bulgaria]]n game developer company [[Haemimont Games]]. It was released March 31, 2000 in the West. The game was met with moderate success; however, it got mild recognition and audience when it was published as a demo in several gaming [[magazines]]. == Gameplay == The gameplay is set in a fictional medieval age. The game is a basic real time strategy game that resembles the gameplay of the ''[[Age of Empires]]'' series. The basic goal is to conquer the neighbouring [[monarchy|kingdom]]s and destroy all traces of them, or destroy their [[castle]]s, depending on the selected playing mode. There are many different buildings and characters player can produce, each depending on which of the three [[Race (human categorization)|races]] the player chooses to play as: European, Asian or Arabian. The main differences are the types of special buildings and the types of troops available. There are four types of resources a player has to gather: food, wood, stone and gold. Food can be gathered by harvesting crops, milking cows or killing them for meat, as well as fishing if the map has lakes or rivers. Wood is gathered by chopping down trees, and gold and stone are gathered by mining. All units have health (hit points) but sorcerers also have mana which gradually regenerates when used to cast spells or summon creatures. The main buildings that can be constructed by all three races are houses, farms, blacksmiths, workshops, barracks, stables, towers, walls, gates and inns. The players usually starts the game with a castle and a few peasants. All types of resources can be carried to the castle. Building houses increases the population limit. Farms can be used to produce cows and also as a place to gather food. Stables are required for some types of mounted soldiers, and blacksmiths provide various improvements to units' armour and fighting skills. Workshops are used to build siege machines. Towers are used for defence. Inns are the place where the player can exchange resources and later hire mercenaries and heroes. Docks can be built to fishing and travelling across the sea. There are a number of elite buildings that are specific for each of the three races. For example, Europeans can build a cathedral, Asians a Shaolin monastery and Arabians a mosque. Another important building is the magician's tower where the player can create sorcerers who can summon different creatures - giants and bats (Europeans), genies (Arabians) and dragons (Asians). There are also many other buildings that create units unique to the race the player is playing. There is also a campaign option for single players in which the player must complete specific goals, such as destroying an enemy force, or protecting a citadel from attack. The campaign has a total of 20 missions.[[Image:Tzarburdenofthecrownscreenshot.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Screenshot of gameplay in ''Tzar: The Burden of the Crown'']] The game also includes a map editor where players can create their own maps to play on with strategically placed rivers, forests, and resources to use to build their armies with. The game is best known for the first ever implementation of a full experience system for every unit in a RTS game. {{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} The game doesn't have the commonly known system of ''[[Warcraft III]]'' for heroes but still every unit has the potential to reach level twelve and thus gaining a heroic status. There is no limit of the "hero" units a player can have, as long as they can keep them alive. The game was considered by [[Linux Game Publishing]] to be ported to [[Linux]], it was however rejected due to concerns within the company about its gameplay and after hearing negative comments about the game from the Linux gaming community.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120305205726/http://www.linuxgames.com/?s=Tzar Tzar related posts] [[LinuxGames]] == Plot == The kingdom of Keanor is under attack by dark forces and much lie in ruins. The old king has died and the son Prince Sartor's whereabouts are unknown. Sartor is raised as a lumberjack in a village, unaware of his royal lineage as Prince. One day, mercenaries seeking Sartor raid the village, killing his uncle. A wizard named Ghiron arrives in time and saves him, revealing his royal lineage and promises to help restore the kingdom to its previous glory. Ghiron takes him to find allies, such as his father's guard captain Woolin. They save the capitol from being completely destroyed. The trio seek more and more allies, growing enough to be confident in the final battle. Having enough resources, they lead massive armies against the Messiah of Evil, the manifestation of evil on Earth. Sartor slowly gains allies. He travels far and wide to find people. He finds allies in the Asians on a far northern continent and finds favor when he kills their old time foes. Sartor soon finds Arabian allies on a far continent. He gets taken prisoner one time and his allies break him out of his imprisonment. Eventually, he gets the confidence and his allies to find the final allies. Then the now-King Sartor leads his army to defeat the Messiah of Evil and his city in one large battle. In the end, he recognizes that evil shall always remain. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GamePro = {{Rating|3.0|5}}{{cite web | author=Olafson, Peter | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050408193132/http://gamepro.com/computer/pc/games/reviews/5661.shtml | url=http://gamepro.com/computer/pc/games/reviews/5661.shtml | work=[[GamePro]] | archivedate=April 8, 2005 | title=''Tzar: Burden of the Crown'' | date=May 22, 2000 | deadurl=yes | df= }} | CGW = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web | author=Chick, Tom | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010211032159/http://www.zdnet.com/cgw/stories/main/0,11529,2577716,00.html | url=http://www.zdnet.com/cgw/stories/main/0,11529,2577716,00.html | work=[[Computer Gaming World]] | archivedate=March 11, 2001 | title=A Tzar is Born | date=June 6, 2000 | deadurl=yes | df= }} | PCGUS = 78%{{cite journal | author=Brenesal, Barry| journal=[[PC Gamer US]] | url=http://www.pcgamer.com/archives/2005/06/tzar.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080203035954/http://www.pcgamer.com/archives/2005/06/tzar.html | archivedate=February 3, 2008 | title=''Tzar'' | deadurl=yes | df= }} | rev1 = ''[[Computer Games Magazine]]'' | rev1Score = {{rating|3|5}}{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040815171548/http://www.cgonline.com/reviews/tzar-01-r1.html |url=http://www.cgonline.com/reviews/tzar-01-r1.html |title=Too Heavy to Lift |author=Cobb, Jim | date=May 20, 2000 |work=[[Computer Games Magazine]] |archivedate=August 15, 2004 |deadurl=yes |df= }} }} ''Tzar'' became a hit in Spain,{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040907063053/http://www.meristation.com:80/sc/noticias/noticia.asp?c=GEN&n=3527| url=http://www.meristation.com:80/sc/noticias/noticia.asp?c=GEN&n=3527 | title=''The Longest Journey'' proporciona a FX su cuarto CD-ROM de oro | date=November 14, 2001 | author=Meix, Joan Isern | work=MeriStation | archivedate=September 7, 2004 | deadurl=yes }} with sales of 50,000 units in the region by November 2000.{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031126062120/http://www.meristation.com:80/sc/noticias/noticia.asp?c=GEN&n=2626 | url=http://www.meristation.com:80/sc/noticias/noticia.asp?c=GEN&n=2626 | title=FX inicia su línea económica | date=November 29, 2000 | archivedate=November 26, 2003 | author=Meix, Joan Isern | work=MeriStation | deadurl=yes }} {{-}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://tza.red Tzared] Tzar for web browsers and Android *[http://www.haemimontgames.com/tzar/ ''Tzar: The Burden of the Crown'' official website] *{{moby game|id=/tzar-the-burden-of-the-crown|name=''The Tzar: Burden of the Crown''}} {{Haemimont}} [[Category:2000 video games]] [[Category:Cancelled Linux games]] [[Category:Real-time strategy video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/64.124.124.215|64.124.124.215]] ([[User talk:64.124.124.215|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=October 2016}} {{lead too short|date=January 2018}} }}
[[File:John Carlos, Tommie Smith, Peter Norman 1968cr.jpg |thumb|Gold medallist [[Tommie Smith]] (center) and bronze medalist [[John Carlos]] (right) showing the [[raised fist]] on the podium after the 200 m race at the [[1968 Summer Olympics]]; both wear [[Olympic Project for Human Rights]] badges. [[Peter Norman]] (silver medalist, left) from Australia also wears an OPHR badge in solidarity with Smith and Carlos.]]
Protests during the playing of the [[United States national anthem]] have had many causes, including civil rights, anti-conscription and anti-war, anti-nationalism, and religious reservations. "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" was adopted as the official national anthem by U.S. President [[Woodrow Wilson]] in 1916, and was made the national anthem by a congressional resolution on March 3, 1931. Before that time, protests also occurred when a number of songs were used as unofficial national anthems, including "[[My Country, 'Tis of Thee]]" and "[[Hail, Columbia]]".
==Early examples== In 1892, three men, including a friend of [[Ida B. Wells]], were [[lynching|lynched]] by a white mob while in police custody in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], in an event known as the [[Peoples Grocery|Peoples Grocery lynching]]. The act sparked a national outcry. At a meeting of one thousand people at Bethel A. M. E. Church, Reverend W. Gaines' call for the crowd to sing the then ''de facto'' national anthem, "[[My Country, 'Tis of Thee]]", but the call was refused, one member of the audience declaring, "I don't want to sing that song until this country is what it claims to be, 'sweet land of liberty'".<ref name=sing/> The Reverend substituted the Civil War-era song about the abolitionist martyr, "[[John Brown's Body]]". Well's husband, [[Ferdinand Lee Barnett (Chicago)|Ferdinand L. Barnett]], closed the meeting appealing for calm and a careful response, but also expressing great frustration and concern that the violence against blacks may one day lead to reprisals.<ref name=sing>Wouldn't Sing America," ''The Evening World'' (New York, New York) March 28, 1892, page 3, accessed September 16, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6654115/wouldnt_sing_america_the_evening/, Not Their Country, ''The Decatur Herald'' (Decatur, Illinois) March 29, 1892, page 1, accessed September 16, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6657652/not_their_country_the_decatur_herald/</ref>
==Early 20th century== [[File:Goldman.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Emma Goldman]] was imprisoned for two years after opposing conscription in the US during World War I.]] Refusal to stand during the national anthem became a widespread form of protest during [[World War I]]. In some cases, this was related to protest of [[conscription]].<ref>YMCA Boys Force A Slacker to Salute, The St. Louis Star and Times (St. Louis, Missouri) June 1, 1917, page 3, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116016//</ref> It was also associated with support for [[Socialism]],<ref>Asked to Resign, The Los Angeles Times (Los Angeles, California) October 30, 1917, page 13, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116078/asked_to_resign_the_los_angeles_times/</ref><ref>Men who Sat While Anthem was Played Escape Fines, Jail, The Oregon Daily Journal (Portland, Oregon) June 18, 1918, page 4, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116139//</ref> [[Bolshevism]],<ref>Disturbers Cheer the Bolshevists and Show Contempt For Anthem, Harrisburg Telegraph (Harrisburg, Pennsylvania) December 9, 1918, page 16, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116158//</ref> or [[Communism]]. In one case, supporters of the Communism refused to stand during the song at a trial of [[Emma Goldman]].<ref>Reds Turned Out at Trial of Emma, The Sun (New York, New York) July 7, 1917, page 4, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116037/reds_turned_out_at_trial_of_emma_the/</ref> The act of protest was very controversial, and many people were highly offended, so that even accidentally remaining seated could result in violence.<ref>Labor Delegates Strike Man who Spurns Anthem, The St. Louis Star and Times (St. Louis, Missouri) December 10, 1917, page 3, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116113//</ref>
Protests during the anthem continued after World War I. For example, during the build-up towards [[World War II]], a group of students at [[Haverford College]] in [[Philadelphia]] refused to stand because they felt the custom was leading to "rabid nationalism".<ref>Students Refuse to Stand While Anthem is Sung, Wilkes=Barre Evening News (Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania) May 31, 1934, page 21, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116195//</ref> In 1943 in [[Arizona]] a federal judge ruled that members of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] cannot be suspended from school for refusing to stand during the national anthem.<ref>Judge Rules for Religious Sect in Fight Over National Anthem, The San Bernardino County Sun, (San Bernardino, California) August 30, 1963, page 11, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116227//</ref>
==1960s and 1970s==
[[File:Jane Fonda 1975d.jpg|thumb|left|[[Jane Fonda]] at an anti-Vietnam War conference in The Hague in January 1975]] In the 1960s, refusal to stand during the anthem took place for a number of reasons. In the late 1960s, the protest became increasingly common among athletes and at schools, both as a protest of the [[Vietnam War]] and as a protest of nationalism. In December 1968, Chris Wood, co-captain of the [[Adelbert College]] basketball team was removed from the team for not standing, saying, "We believe in the fellowship of man. We don't believe in nationalism."<ref>Didn't Stand For Anthem, Is Dismissed, El Paso Herald-Post (el Paso, Texas) December 11, 1968, page 24, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116260//</ref> Five white high school students were suspended in [[Cumberland, Maryland]] in February 1970.<ref>Suspend Students Refusing to Stand for Pledge, Anthem, The Daily Courier (Connellsville, Pennsylvania) February 25, 1970, page 19, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116277//</ref> A federal judge [[Joseph P. Kinneary]] ordered reinstatement of a pair of students in Columbus, Ohio, saying that forcing anyone to participate in "symbolic patriotic ceremonies" against their will was a violation of the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment to the US Constitution]].<ref>Anthem Protest Pair Reinstated, Lubbuck Avalanche-Journal (Lubbock, Texas (July 8, 1970), page 75, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116307/anthem_protest_pair_reinstated_lubbuck/</ref> In November 1970, [[Kaye Stevens]] refused to sing the national anthem before a [[NFL]] game between the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] and [[Kansas City Chiefs]], although she had sung the previous week when the Steelers played the [[New York Jets]]. She said she was protesting the Steelers planned expenditure of $37 million on the new [[Three Rivers Stadium]] when local officials were underfunding treatment for drug users.<ref>Refuses to Sing Anthem, Traverse City Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan) November 14, 1970, page 13, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116365//</ref>
From 1968 onwards, [[Jimi Hendrix]] performed an instrumental version using feedback, distortion and other effects to deconstruct the music with the sonic images of rockets and bombs. Common interpretations link this to a protest against the [[Vietnam War]], opposed to Hendrix own explanation: "We're all Americans ... it was like 'Go America!'... We play it the way the air is in America today. The air is slightly static, see".{{sfn|Cross|2005|p=271}}
[[Donald Sutherland]], [[Gary Goodrow]], [[Peter Boyle]], and [[Jane Fonda]] developed an anti-war comedy show which featured a skit about people refusing to stand during the anthem which toured about 20 cities in 1971.<ref>Anti-War Show has SRO Crowd, The Troy Record (Troy, New York) March 15, 1927, page 1, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116407/antiwar_show_has_sro_crowd_the_troy/</ref>
===Civil rights movement=== At the same time, Civil Rights became an important cause which led to anthem protests. The [[1968 Olympics Black Power salute]] was a political demonstration conducted by [[African-American]] athletes [[Tommie Smith]] and [[John Carlos]] during their medal ceremony at the [[1968 Summer Olympics]] in the [[Estadio Olímpico Universitario|Olympic Stadium]] in [[Mexico City]]. After having won gold and bronze medals, respectively, in the [[200 metres at the Olympics|200 meter]] running event, they turned on the podium to face their flags, and to hear the American national anthem, "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]". Each athlete [[Raised fist|raised a black-gloved fist]], and kept them raised until the anthem had finished. In addition, Smith, Carlos, and Australian silver medalist [[Peter Norman]] all wore human rights badges on their jackets. In his autobiography, ''Silent Gesture'', Smith stated that the gesture was not a "[[Black Power]]" salute, but a "human rights salute". The event is regarded as one of the most overtly political statements in the history of the modern [[Olympic Games]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2094-2393575,00.html |work=The Sunday Times |location=London |last=Lewis |first=Richard |date=8 October 2006 |title=Caught in Time: Black Power salute, Mexico, 1968 |accessdate=9 November 2008 }}</ref>
In 1969, [[University of Wyoming]] coach [[Lloyd Eaton]] dismissed 14 black football players who requested to wear black armbands to protest the racial slurs they faced during games, particularly against [[BYU]]. When the two teams played in 1971, about 50 students at UW refused to stand during the national anthem and wore black armbands during the game.<ref>Wyoming President Says Black 14 Issues Remain, The Daily Herald (Provo, Utah) October 21, 1971, page 19, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116500//</ref> Another place where African Americans refused to stand during the anthem in 1971 was at [[Northern Illinois University]] basketball games, which led to widespread criticism.<ref>Banning Anthem Discraceful Action, Belvidere Daily Republican (Belvidere, Illinois) December 20, 1971, page 6, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116534//</ref>
The protests became widespread, and in some cases, arrangements were made for the anthem to be played before athletes left the locker room. Lew Alcindor, later known as [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]], began to refuse to stand at [[UCLA]] basketball games, and in response the anthem was played before the players left the locker room in the UCLA-[[University of Washington]] game.<ref>Walt Brown, Athletes, Celebrities Personal Moments: The 60s and 70s, AuthorHouse, Mar 10, 2016</ref> The same was done when the five starters of [[Florida State University]]'s basketball team, all African American, played [[Tulane University]] in 1971 in [[New Orleans]].<ref>FSU Starters Refuse to Stand for Anthem, Albuquerque Journal (Albuquerque, New Mexico) January 14, 1971, page 25, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116445//</ref>
[[File:Vincent_Matthews_1968.jpg|thumb|[[Vincent Matthews (athlete)|Vincent Matthews]] in 1968]] During the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in [[Munich]], [[Vincent Matthews (athlete)|Vincent Matthews]] of [[New York City]] and [[Wayne Collett]] of [[Santa Monica, California]] came in first and second in the 400 meter race. The pair refused to stand at attention on the victory stand to boos and whistles from the crowd.<ref>Athletes Disregard National Anthem, The Bonham Daily Favorite (Bonham, Texas) September 8, 1972, page 5, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116591//</ref> The pair were barred from running in the 1,600 meter relay later in the games.<ref>Two US Athletes Barred From Further Olympic Actions, Traverse City Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan) September 8, 1972, page 14, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116613//</ref>
Civil rights based protests continued into the late 1970s, In 1978, a student was barred from receiving his diploma in [[Dayton, Ohio]] for refusing to sing.<ref>Won't Sing Anthem, so no Diploma, The Pantagraph (Bloomington, Illinois) June 4, 1978, page 10, accessed October 21, 2016 at https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7116628/wont_sing_anthem_so_no_diploma_the/</ref>
==Turn of the millennium== On August 24, 1990, Irish pop singer [[Sinead O'Connor]] threatened to boycott her scheduled performance that night at the [[Garden State Arts Center]] in [[Holmdel Township, New Jersey]], if the U.S. national anthem were played. In her own words, she explained,
{{blockquote|I sincerely harbor no disrespect for America or Americans, but I have a policy of not having any national anthems played before my concerts in any country, including my own, because they have nothing to do with music in general...I am concerned though, because today, we're seeing other artists arrested at their own concerts...There is a disturbing trend towards censorship of music and art in this country and people should be alarmed over that far more than my actions...}}
The Center gave in to her demands, but not without controversy. [[Frank Sinatra]] criticized her the following evening while performing at the same venue, stating that he wished that he could "kick her in the ass." [[New York state]] Senator Nicholas Spano urged people to boycott O'Connor's subsequent show in [[Saratoga, New York|Saratoga]], saying "I'm sure Ms. O'Connor would be the first to complain if someone tried to censor her performance, yet she is trying to censor the national anthem by refusing to perform where it is played."<ref>{{cite news|title=Legislator Urges Boycott Over Sinead's Anthem Ban|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-08-28/entertainment/ca-409_1_national-anthem|accessdate=September 28, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=Times Wire Services|publisher=Times-Mirror Co.|page=10}}</ref>
In 1996, there was protest in the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]], when [[Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf]], guard for the [[Denver Nuggets]], refused to stand during the anthem before games in protest of [[Criticism of Islam|anti-Islamic]] rhetoric. He was suspended for his actions and received hostile responses and death threats, but the issue receiving widespread attention.<ref name=Hostile>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/09/sports/rodriguez-yankees-home-hostile-home.html?pagewanted=2&ref=sports&pagewanted=all Home, Hostile Home], ''[[New York Times]]'' (August 8, 2013)</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jim Hodges|title=NBA Sits Abdul-Rauf for Stance on Anthem|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-03-13/sports/sp-46409_1_mahmoud-abdul-rauf|date=March 13, 1996|accessdate=December 6, 2016|work=The Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>Jackson, Sarah J. Black Celebrity, Racial Politics, and the Press: Framing Dissent. Routledge, 2014. p117-118</ref> It was noted that at the same time [[Sam Perkins]], who played for the [[Seattle SuperSonics]], is a [[Jehovah's Witness]] who refuse to pledge allegiance to any government; he stood apart from his teammates during the national anthem. [[George Shinn]], owner of the [[Charlotte Hornets]], threatened to trade any player who refused to stand.<ref>[[McCallum, Jack]], [https://www.si.com/vault/1996/03/25/211232/oh-say-should-we-sing-playing-the-national-anthem-is-a-vestige-of-wartime-fervor-so-why-is-it-still-a-part-of-us-sports-events "Oh Say Should We Sing?"] ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', March 25, 1996, accessed October 21, 2016.</ref><ref name="Abrams2013">Abrams, Roger I. ''Playing Tough: The World of Sports and Politics''. UPNE, 2013. p4</ref> After his suspension, Abdul-Rauf stood, but with his head bowed in silent prayer.<ref>Abrams 2014, p 125</ref>
In 2003, two women's basketball players, Toni Smith of [[Manhattanville College]] and Deidra Chatman of the [[Virginia Cavaliers women's basketball|University of Virginia]], made headlines for refusing to face the flag during the national anthem. Chatman, a Jehovah's Witness, protested for one game in March 2003 due to her anti-war views in light of the then-current tensions between the U.S. and [[Iraq]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reedy|first1=Jim|title=U-Va. Protest Takes an About Face|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/2003/03/04/u-va-protest-takes-an-about-face/2b9a1099-5552-4861-9775-cda0579ba36a|accessdate=September 28, 2017|work=Washington Post|publisher=WP Company|date=March 4, 2003}}</ref> Smith, who had been boycotting the anthem all season long before being finally noticed in February 2003, said that she was also protesting the United States' involvement in Iraq, as well as a growing disparity between the rich and the poor. During one of her team's games on February 23, 2003, a fan named Jerry Kiley, a self-described [[Vietnam conflict|Vietnam]] veteran, ran onto the court and confronted her with an American flag, saying, "She has not earned the right to disrespect the flag."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pennington|first1=Bill|title=Player's Protest Over the Flag Divides Fans|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/26/sports/college-basketball-player-s-protest-over-the-flag-divides-fans.html|accessdate=September 28, 2017|work=New York Times|publisher=NY Times Company|date=February 26, 2003}}</ref>
In 2004, [[Carlos Delgado]] of the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] [[Major League Baseball]] team decided he would no longer stand during the song, "God Bless America" out of protest at America's wars in the Middle East.<ref name="Abrams2013"/>
==2016–present== {{main|U.S. national anthem protests (2016–present)}} [[File:Colin Kaepernick in 2013.jpg|thumb|[[Colin Kaepernick]] in 2013]] During 2016, several professional athletes protested [[police brutality]] during the [[United States]] (U.S.) [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]]. The protests began in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) after [[San Francisco 49ers]] [[quarterback]] (QB) [[Colin Kaepernick]] sat during the anthem, as opposed to the tradition of standing, before his team's third [[National Football League preseason|preseason]] game of [[2016 NFL season|2016]]. Kaepernick also sat during the first two preseason games, but he went unnoticed.<ref name="SB">{{cite web|last1=Sandritter|first1=Mark|title=A timeline of Colin Kaepernick's national anthem protest and the NFL players who joined him|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2016/9/11/12869726/colin-kaepernick-national-anthem-protest-seahawks-brandon-marshall-nfl|publisher=SB Nation|accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref> The protests have generated mixed reactions and have since spread to other U.S. sports leagues.
Stemming from the Kaepernick controversy, before the beginning of the [[2016 World Cup of Hockey]] tournament in [[Toronto|Toronto, Canada]], Team USA coach [[John Tortorella]] told in an interview that if any one of his players were to sit out during the anthem, they would sit on the bench for the entire duration of the game.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/world-cup-of-hockey/tortorella-will-sit-anthem-protests-team-usa/|title=Tortorella 'will sit' any Team USA player who protests anthem - Sportsnet.ca|newspaper=Sportsnet.ca|access-date=2017-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}} * {{cite book|last=Cross|first=Charles R.|title=Room Full of Mirrors: A Biography of Jimi Hendrix|year=2005|publisher=Hyperion|isbn=978-0-7868-8841-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zl7ZxkviIEQC&dq |ref=harv}}
[[Category:Anti-racism]] [[Category:Anti-war]] [[Category:Civil rights protests in the United States]] [[Category:U.S. national anthem protests (2016–present)|*]] [[Category:Islam and politics]] [[Category:Jehovah's Witnesses]] [[Category:Music and politics]] [[Category:Police brutality in the United States]] [[Category:Politics and race in the United States]] [[Category:Politics and sports]] [[Category:Protests in the United States]] [[Category:Religion and politics]] [[Category:Sports controversies]] [[Category:The Star-Spangled Banner]]

{{For|the video game company|Smart Bomb Interactive}} '''Wildworks''' is an international site-specific [[theatre]] company based in [[Cornwall]], England.
They specialise in large-scale outdoor promenade performances.<ref>{{cite web|author=This is Cornwall |url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Alive-breathing-new-dimension/story-11395982-detail/story.html |title=Alive and breathing in new dimension |publisher=Western Morning News |date=2009-05-29 |accessdate=2016-02-15}}</ref>
They were formed in 2005 by [[Bill Mitchell (artistic director)|Bill Mitchell]],<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/theatre_performance/past%20exhibitions/Display:%20Collaborators/Special%20Exhibits/collaborators_special_exhibits_wildworks_wings/index.html |title=Theatre and performance - Victoria and Albert Museum |publisher=Vam.ac.uk |date=2010-02-19 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> initially growing out of [[Kneehigh Theatre]] Company.<ref>http://www.plymouth.ac.uk/pages/view.asp?page=24458</ref> The company utilises specific sites such as harbours, quarries, villages and factories and works closely with the local community.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Productions== * ''[[A Very Old Man with Enormous Wings|A Very Old Man With Enormous Wings]]'' - 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seasaltcornwall.co.uk/acatalog/feature_wildworks_0707.php |title=Wildworks Theatre Company | Seasalt Stories |publisher=Seasaltcornwall.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> Adapted from a short story by [[Gabriel Garcia Marquez]]<ref>[http://www.intentional.co.uk/oldman/index.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723113743/http://www.intentional.co.uk/oldman/index.html |date=July 23, 2008 }}</ref> * ''Souterrain''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/souterrain/|title=Souterrain - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - 2006 - 07 Performed in [[Dolcoath Mine]] [[Camborne]] Cornwall<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsW/wildworks.html |title=Wildworks - complete guide to the Playwright, Plays, Theatres, Agent |publisher=Doollee.com |date=2010-03-25 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>, Stanmer Park [[Brighton]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ltdb.co.uk/node/13562 |title=Wildworks | London Theatre Database |publisher=Ltdb.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>, * ''The Beautiful Journey''<ref>{{cite news|author=Lyn Gardner |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/may/27/theatre-wildworks-beautiful-journey |title=Lyn Gardner on Wildworks theatre company's new production The Beautiful Journey | Stage |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2009-05-27|accessdate=2011-07-07 |location=London}}</ref> - 2009 performed in [[HMNB Devonport]] [[Plymouth]] and Wallsend Newcastle. * ''The Enchanted Palace'' - 2010 until 2012, [[Kensington Palace|Kensington Palace London]]<ref>{{cite news|author=Lyn Gardner |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/apr/13/enchanted-palace-review |title=Enchanted Palace | Theatre review | Stage |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2010-04-13|accessdate=2011-07-07 |location=London}}</ref> * ''[[Passion of Jesus|The Passion]]''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/the-passion/|title=The Passion - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - [[Port Talbot|Port Talbot, South Wales]], 2011<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/apr/24/the-passion-port-talbot-review|title=The Passion – review|last=Gardner|first=Lyn|date=2011-04-24|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref>. In collaboration with [[Michael Sheen]] and [[National Theatre Wales]] * ''Babel''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/babel/|title=BABEL - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> ''-'' May 2012 performed in Caledonian Park, London. In collaboration with [[Battersea Arts Centre]], [[Lyric Theatre (Hammersmith)|Lyric Hammersmith]], [[Theatre Royal Stratford East]], and The Young Vic. * ''Ark-Ive''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/ark-ive-national-theatr-7970|title=Theatre review: Ark-ive at National Theatre's Theatre Square|website=www.britishtheatreguide.info|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> - August 2012, [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre London]] * ''Nablus, Palestine'' - September<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/nablus-palestine/|title=Nablus - Palestine - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> 2013 * ''100: The Day Our World Changed'' - August 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://heligan.com/explore/news/100-the-day-our-world-changed1/|title=100 The Day Our World Changed {{!}} The Lost Gardens of Heligan|website=heligan.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref> performed at [[Lost Gardens of Heligan|The Lost Gardens of Heligan, Cornwall]]. Co-commissioned by [[Lost Gardens of Heligan|The Lost Gardens of Heligan]] and [[14-18 NOW|14-18NOW.]] * ''The Yule-Tide Ark-Ive''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/yule-tide-ark-ive/|title=The Yule-Tide Ark-Ive - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - Christmas 2014 and 2015, [[Eden Project|The Eden Project, Cornwall]]. * ''Once Upon A Castle''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/once-upon-a-castle/|title=Once and Twice Upon a Castle - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - [[Gaasbeek Castle|Kasteel Van Gasbeek]], Belgium, 2014 * ''Twice Upon A Castle'' - [[Gaasbeek Castle|Kasteel Van Gasbeek]], Belgium, 2015 * ''Wolf's Child''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/wolfs-child/|title=WOLF'S CHILD - NORFOLK 2015 - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/may/17/wolfs-child-extraordinary-exploration-tamed|title=Wolf’s Child review – an extraordinary exploration of what it is to be tamed|last=Clapp|first=Susannah|date=2015-05-17|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref>, [[Felbrigg Hall]], Norfolk. In partnership with Norfolk and Norwich Festival<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nnfestival.org.uk/about-us/past-festivals/2015-2/|title=2015 {{!}} Norfolk & Norwich Festival|website=Norfolk & Norwich Festival|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref>. * ''Dream City - Tunis -'' 2015<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/tunis/|title=Dream City- Tunis - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> * ''A Great Night Out'' - The Point, Sunderland<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sunderlandecho.com/whats-on/review-a-great-night-out-by-wildworks-the-point-sunderland-1-7888013|title=REVIEW: A Great Night Out, by WildWorks, The Point, Sunderland|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en}}</ref>, May 2016. In collaboration with Cultural Spring. * ''The Great Survey of Hastings''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/the-great-survey-of-hastings/|title=The Great Survey of Hastings - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - Ladies Parlour, [[Hastings Castle|Hastings Castle Ruins]], October 2016 delivered as part of the ROOT1066 festival and based on the [[Domesday Book]]. * ''Wolf's Child''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wildworks.biz/projects/wolfs-child-2017/|title=Wolfs Child 2017 - Wild Works|work=Wild Works|access-date=2018-03-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> - 2017, Trelowarren Estate, Cornwall. ==The Company== * Bill Mitchell, Director *Peter Boyden, Executive Producer
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.wildworks.biz/ Official website] *[http://www.whatsonwales.co.uk/interviews/i/20449/ Wildworks Interview]
